an4.196:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
an4.196:1.2: Then Sāḷha and Abhaya the Licchavis went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
an4.196:2.1: “There are, sir, some ascetics and brahmins who advocate crossing the flood by means of two things:
an4.196:2.2: purification of ethics, and mortification in disgust of sin.
an4.196:2.3: What does the Buddha say about this?”
an4.196:3.1: “Sāḷha, purification of ethics is one of the factors of the ascetic life, I say.
an4.196:3.2: But those ascetics and brahmins who teach mortification in disgust of sin—regarding it as essential and clinging to it—are incapable of crossing the flood.
an4.196:3.3: And those ascetics and brahmins whose livelihood and behavior by way of body, speech, and mind, is not pure are also incapable of knowing and seeing, of supreme awakening.
an4.196:4.1: Suppose a man who wanted to cross a river took a sharp axe into a wood.
an4.196:4.2: There he’d see a large green sal tree, straight and young and grown free of defects.
an4.196:4.3: He’d cut it down at the base,
an4.196:4.5: and completely strip off the branches and foliage.
an4.196:4.6: Then he’d trim it with axes and
an4.196:4.9: and sand it with a rock.
an4.196:4.10: Finally, he’d launch out on the river.
an4.196:5.2: Is that man capable of crossing the river?”
an4.196:5.5: Because that green sal tree is well worked on the outside, but inside it’s still not cleared out.
an4.196:5.6: I’d expect that green sal tree to sink, and the man to come to ruin.”
an4.196:6.1: “In the same way, Sāḷha, those ascetics and brahmins who teach mortification in disgust of sin—regarding it as essential and clinging to it—are incapable of crossing the flood.
an4.196:6.2: And those ascetics and brahmins whose livelihood and behavior by way of body, speech, and mind is not pure are also incapable of knowing and seeing, of supreme awakening.
an4.196:7.1: But those ascetics and brahmins who don’t teach mortification in disgust of sin—not regarding it as essential or clinging to it—are capable of crossing the flood.
an4.196:7.2: And those ascetics and brahmins whose behavior by way of body, speech, and mind is pure are also capable of knowing and seeing, of supreme awakening.
an4.196:8.1: Suppose a man who wanted to cross a river took a sharp axe into a wood.
an4.196:8.2: There he’d see a large green sal tree, straight and young and grown free of defects.
an4.196:8.3: He’d cut it down at the base,
an4.196:8.5: and completely strip off the branches and foliage.
an4.196:8.6: Then he’d trim it with axes and
an4.196:8.8: Then he’d take a chisel and completely clear it out inside.
an4.196:8.11: and make it into a boat.
an4.196:8.12: Finally he’d fix it with oars and rudder,
an4.196:8.13: and launch out on the river.
an4.196:9.2: Is that man capable of crossing the river?”
an4.196:9.5: Because that green sal tree is well worked on the outside, cleared out on the inside, made into a boat, and fixed with oars and rudder.
an4.196:9.7: that boat to not sink, and the man to safely make it to the far shore.”
an4.196:10.1: “In the same way, Sāḷha, those ascetics and brahmins who don’t teach mortification in disgust of sin—not regarding it as essential or clinging to it—are capable of crossing the flood.
an4.196:10.2: And those ascetics and brahmins whose behavior by way of body, speech, and mind is pure are also capable of knowing and seeing, of supreme awakening.
an4.196:10.3: Suppose there was a warrior who knew lots of fancy archery tricks.
an4.196:10.4: It is only with these three factors that he becomes worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.
an4.196:10.6: He’s a long-distance shooter, a marksman, and one who shatters large objects.
an4.196:11.1: Just as a warrior is a long-distance shooter,
an4.196:11.2: a noble disciple has right immersion.
an4.196:11.3: A noble disciple with right immersion truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: *all* form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
an4.196:11.4: They truly see any kind of feeling …
an4.196:11.7: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near, *all* consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
an4.196:12.1: Just as a warrior is a marksman,
an4.196:12.2: a noble disciple has right view.
an4.196:12.3: A noble disciple with right view truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
an4.196:13.1: Just as a warrior shatters large objects,
an4.196:13.2: a noble disciple has right freedom.
an4.196:13.3: A noble disciple with right freedom shatters the great mass of ignorance.”
